metadata.titleEn: Global air freeze-thaw index based on observations（1973-2021）
metadata.description: Freeze-thaw index is an important sensitive indicator of climate change, and is also widely used in the study of frozen soil changes. The research on the spatial distribution characteristics and time variation trend of freezing and thawing index in the global scope can provide a basis for the global frozen soil environment assessment, engineering construction and coping with climate change. This data set is based on the daily temperature observation data of more than 14000 stations covering the global land from 1973 to 2021 to calculate the air freezing index (FI) and air melting index (TI). The freezing/thawing index is the cumulative value of the daily average temperature below/above 0 ℃ during the freezing/thawing period. Considering that the index calculation should cover the whole freezing/thawing period and ensure the continuity of the calculation period, the northern hemisphere takes July 1 of that year to June 30 of the next year as a freezing period, and takes January 1 to December 30 of that year as a melting period, while the southern hemisphere has the opposite freezing/thawing period. The stations with missing survey years were not filled, which, on the one hand, avoided the uncertainty error caused by interpolation on the results, and on the other hand, retained the authenticity and accuracy of the data as much as possible. The study of global freeze-thaw index can effectively and comprehensively understand the near surface heat state, and can provide important support for exploring the changes of freeze-thaw state.
metadata.instructions:
File name: Air freezing index (FI) and air melting index (TI) are stored in FI.rar and TI.rar compressed package formats respectively. GSOD in each file_ FI_ 010010-99999. xls or GSOD_ TI_ 010010-99999. xls is stored in this format, representing GSOD (Global Surface Summary of the Day), FI (Air Freezing Index), TI (Air Melting Index), 010010-99999 (Station No.) respectively.
Data reading method: all table files in the dataset can be opened with excel program, and the main contents are station (1-2 columns), longitude and latitude (3-4 columns), altitude (5 columns), annual minute (6 columns), freezing/melting index (7 columns).

background: The freezing/thawing index is an important sensitive indicator of climate change, and also widely used in the permafrost change. The spatial-temporal variations of freezing/thawing index on a global scale can provide a basis for global permafrost environment assessment, engineering construction and climate change. The freezing/thawing index is affected by both latitude and altitude, and has obvious climatic distribution characteristics. The trend of the freezing/thawing index reflects that the global climate is warming with different degrees, especially in high latitudes and high altitudes, and the warming trend in the cold season is greater than that in the warm season.
research objective: Based on the daily observed temperature data from 1973 to 2021 covering the global land and more than 14,000 stations, we calculate the air freezing/thawing index and analyze its spatial and temporal variation characteristics, and discuss the relationship with geographical factors.
challenges: However, the changes of the freezing/thawing index tended to be flat at the beginning of the 21st century.
dataset: Based on the daily observed temperature data from 1973 to 2021 covering the global land and more than 14,000 stations.
findings: Results show that the global average freezing index is 610.8 ℃·d in the past 49 years, the maximum value is 19,653.3 ℃·d, 667.9 ℃·d in the Northern Hemisphere larger than 152.4 ℃·d in the Southern Hemisphere. The global average thawing index is 4,709.6 ℃·d, the maximum value is 11,217.0 ℃·d, and 4,444.5 ℃·d in the Northern Hemisphere smaller than 6,927.3 ℃·d in the Southern Hemisphere. From 1973 to 2021, the freezing index decreased by an average of 36% globally (net change of -160.2 ℃·d), an average decrease of 68% in the high latitudes under the snow climate zone. The thawing index increased by an average of 11% globally (net change of 437.5 ℃·d), while an average increase of 16% in the high latitudes under the snow climate zone.

background: Climate change is dramatically altering montane lakes and affecting species distributions (Hotaling et al., 2017). Montane lakes are considered to be great natural evolutionary laboratories because of their isolation and high endemism; this combination reduces confounding effects and, thus, makes evolutionary patterns easier to interpret (Salzburger, 2018; Whittaker et al., 2017). However, tens of thousands of montane or glacial lakes along the Alpine–Himalayan belt and Rocky Mountain ranges have been largely unexplored, and global biodiversity patterns in montane lakes remain relatively unknown. Climate warming has resulted in species homogenization and even extinction in these systems (Hotaling et al., 2017). As they are threatened by climate change, mountain lake systems have been considered to be extremely vulnerable centers of diversity for cold-adapted biotas (Herbert et al., 2016). Understanding the impact of past climate cooling on evolutionary history of montane-lake species may improve our ability to assess the threats to cold-water species posed by global warming. Global cooling took place from the Mid-Miocene to Pliocene, and intensified in the Pleistocene (Ho et al., 2019; Westerhold et al., 2020; Zachos et al., 2001). This cooling trend resulted in the separation of huge lake complexes along the Alpine–Himalayan belt (Neubauer et al., 2015; Wu et al., 2008) and isolation of lacustrine basins in the Rocky Mountain ranges (Galloway et al., 2011), leading to an increase in the number of montane lakes.
research objective: We test this hypothesis by using phylogeographic analysis and niche modeling of the Holarctic crustacean Gammarus lacustris with global sampling comprised of 567 sequenced individuals and 3180 occurrence records. Here, we integrate phylogenetic analysis and niche modeling to evaluate the impacts of past climate cooling on the global expansion of G. lacustris, and apply this knowledge to forecast future distributions under climate change.
challenges: While more samples would be desirable to strengthen predictions in this area, their absence has limited influence on our inferences globally because we built separate ENMs for each biogeographic region.
methods: Genomic DNA was extracted from the legs of specimens using the Tiangen Genomic DNA kit following the manufacturer’s protocol. For the 203-tip data set, more conservative genes were used to resolve the deep evolutionary relationships of the family Gammaridae, including fragments of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S) and 10 nuclear genes (28S, 18S, EF1a, AK, PEPCK, HSP70, NaK, GAPDH, PDI, and H3). For the 567-tip data set, relatively fast-evolving genes were selected to demonstrate a clear chronosequence of divergence in biogeographic regions, including fragments of three mitochondrial genes (COI, COIII, and 16S) and five nuclear genes (28S, EF1a, AK, PEPCK, and HSP70). PCR products were sent to Sangon Biotech (Beijing) for bidirectional Sanger sequencing, then forward and reverse strands were edited and assembled into contigs using Squencher v4.2 (Gene Codes Corporation). Sequences were aligned for each gene independently using ClustalX v2.0.9 (Larkin et al., 2007) and manually adjusted in MacClade v4.06 (Maddison & Maddison, 2000). Maximum parsimony (MP) and maximum likelihood (ML) analyses were conducted for single gene and concatenated 203-tip and 567-tip data sets. A Bayesian inference (BI) tree was generated for the 203-tip dataset in MrBayes v3.2.1 (Ronquist et al., 2012). For the 567-tip dataset, Bayesian analysis failed to converge in MrBayes and so subsequent analyses were conducted using ExaBayes v1.5.1 (Aberer et al., 2014), which is designed specifically for large data sets.
dataset: Here, we focus on the global expansion of G. lacustris using a dataset that includes 567 specimens covering montane lakes from all major geographic regions across Eurasia and North America. The 203-tip data set, with well-supported calibration points, was used to estimate the crown age of the G. lacustris clade.
findings: We found that the species arose in Tian Shan in Central Asia and dispersed into montane lakes along the Alps, Himalayas, Tibet, East Asia, and the North American Rocky Mountain ranges, with accelerated diversification rates outside Tian Shan. Climatically suitable regions for geographic lineages of G. lacustris were larger during cooling periods (LGM), but smaller during warming periods (Mid-Holocene). In the future (2070) scenario, potential distributions in the Himalayas, North Tibet, South Tibet and North America are predicted to expand, whereas ranges in East Asia, Europe and Tian Shan will decline. Our results suggest that Mid-Miocene-to-Pleistocene continuous cooling promoted multiple independent dispersal events out of Tian Shan due to increased availability of montane lakes via “budding” of lineages. Montane lakes are conduits through which cold-adapted amphipods globally dispersed, dominating circumboreal lakes. However, future climate warming is likely to force organisms to shift upward in altitude and northward in latitude, leading to a future change in local populations.

Definition.Question: What is the 'freezing/thawing index' and how is it used in climate change studies?
Definition.Answer: The freezing/thawing index is an important sensitive indicator of climate change. It is widely used in the study of permafrost change and reflects both spatial and temporal variations. The index is affected by latitude and altitude and has notable climatic distribution characteristics. In climate change studies, understanding the trend of the freezing/thawing index helps assess global climate warming, especially in high latitudes and altitudes, where warming trends are more pronounced in the cold season.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with calculating the freezing/thawing index globally?
Definition.Answer: One of the challenges in calculating the freezing/thawing index globally is the flat trend of changes observed at the beginning of the 21st century. Additionally, ensuring the continuity of the calculation period is important to accurately capture the entire freezing/thawing period. Furthermore, dealing with missing data at certain stations without interpolation is another challenge, as it maintains data accuracy but can affect the completeness of the dataset.

Definition.Question: What does the data collection method for the global freezing/thawing index entail?
Definition.Answer: The data collection method for the global freezing/thawing index involves using daily observed temperature data from 1973 to 2021, covering land globally with over 14,000 stations. This data is utilized to calculate the air freezing index (FI) and thawing index (TI), which are cumulative values of daily mean temperatures below or above 0°C during the freezing or thawing period, respectively. The method prioritizes accuracy and avoids interpolation for missing years to maintain data authenticity.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods for calculating the freezing/thawing index using daily observed temperature data compare to techniques used in phylogeographic analysis and niche modeling of Gammarus lacustris?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection for the freezing/thawing index involves using daily observed temperature data from over 14,000 global land stations, focusing on temperature accumulation values below or above 0°C. In contrast, phylogeographic analysis and niche modeling for Gammarus lacustris require genomic DNA extraction and sequencing from specimen samples, along with climatic data for niche modeling. The former relies on meteorological data, while the latter integrates molecular and spatial environmental data.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when analyzing spatial-temporal variations of the freezing/thawing index versus those encountered in forecasting future distributions of Gammarus lacustris under climate change?
Comparison.Answer: Challenges in analyzing the freezing/thawing index include dealing with flat trends at the beginning of the 21st century, whereas forecasting future distributions of Gammarus lacustris is challenged by the absence of samples, which limits prediction strength. The former is concerned with long-term temperature trends, while the latter involves biological and ecological predictions based on genetic and environmental data.

Interpretation.Question: How can the spatial and temporal variations in the freezing/thawing index be interpreted in terms of global climate change trends?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial and temporal variations of the freezing/thawing index indicate that the global climate is warming at different rates, with more significant warming trends observed in high latitudes and high altitudes, particularly during the cold season.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining the accuracy and authenticity of temperature data when dealing with incomplete datasets, and how can these be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining data accuracy and authenticity may arise from incomplete datasets due to missing years of observation at certain stations. To address these, the data collection method avoids interpolation, which could introduce uncertainty, thus preserving the data's original characteristics and reliability.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the observed freezing/thawing index provide insights into the impact of geographical factors on climate patterns?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed freezing/thawing index can reveal the influence of geographical factors such as latitude and altitude on climate patterns, indicating that these factors contribute to the climatic distribution characteristics of the index and its response to global climate variations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for not filling in missing years in the daily temperature observations used for calculating global air freezing and thawing indices?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Missing years in the daily temperature observations were not filled to avoid uncertainty errors that interpolation might introduce, and to preserve the authenticity and accuracy of the data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might the freezing/thawing index have shown a flatter trend at the beginning of the 21st century?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The changes in the freezing/thawing index tended to be flat at the beginning of the 21st century, possibly due to variations in the global climate warming patterns, which might have resulted in less pronounced alterations in the freezing/thawing index during that period.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors might have contributed to the challenges in predicting future distributions of montane lake species using phylogeographic analysis and niche modeling?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: While the absence of additional samples was a limitation, it had a limited influence on global inferences because separate ecological niche models were constructed for each biogeographic region, allowing for tailored predictions despite the challenges.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely outcomes of using phylogeographic analysis and niche modeling in understanding the global expansion of species like Gammarus lacustris under climate change?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using phylogeographic analysis and niche modeling can reveal how past climate cooling influenced species distribution, project future range shifts due to warming, and identify vulnerable regions where species may face habitat loss or need to migrate.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect daily observed temperature data from a global network of over 14,000 stations for calculating freezing/thawing indices?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Collecting daily observed temperature data from a global network of over 14,000 stations is crucial to calculate the air freezing/thawing index as it allows for a comprehensive analysis of spatial and temporal variation characteristics of the index on a global scale. This data provides a basis for assessing the global permafrost environment, supports engineering construction, and aids in understanding climate change impacts.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to use a dataset that includes 567 specimens from montane lakes across major geographic regions for studying species dispersal?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using a dataset that includes 567 specimens from montane lakes across major geographic regions is necessary for studying species dispersal as it provides a comprehensive view of the global expansion patterns of species. This dataset allows researchers to investigate the historical and future climatic suitability of different geographic lineages, enhancing the understanding of how species have dispersed and adapted to changing environmental conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to calculate the air freezing and thawing index from daily observed temperature data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The air freezing and thawing index is calculated using daily observed temperature data from 1973 to 2021, covering global land and more than 14,000 stations. The freezing/thawing index is determined by the cumulative temperature values during freezing/melting periods where the daily average temperature is below/above 0 ℃. The calculation ensures the coverage of the entire freezing/melting period; for the Northern Hemisphere, the period spans from July 1st of the current year to June 30th of the next year for freezing, and from January 1st to December 30th for melting, with opposite periods for the Southern Hemisphere.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What strategies are employed to ensure the authenticity and accuracy of temperature data used in calculating the freezing/thawing index?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The authenticity and accuracy of the temperature data are maintained by not filling in missing data for stations with years of missing observations. This approach avoids uncertainties introduced by interpolation and retains the data's original integrity. The dataset is based on daily observed temperature data from more than 14,000 stations globally, ensuring a comprehensive coverage across different regions.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the accurate calculation of freezing and thawing indices for a global scale?
Enablement.Answer: The calculation of freezing and thawing indices is enabled by using daily observed temperature data from more than 14,000 stations globally, covering the period from 1973 to 2021. This comprehensive dataset allows for the analysis of spatial and temporal variations of the indices.

Enablement.Question: How does the choice of whether or not to interpolate missing data influence the accuracy and reliability of datasets in climate research?
Enablement.Answer: In the dataset, stations with missing years were not interpolated to avoid introducing uncertainty errors and to retain the authenticity and accuracy of the data. This choice impacts the reliability of the dataset by ensuring that only actual observed data are used, reducing the potential for error introduced by interpolation.

Expectation.Question: Why might the changes in the freezing/thawing index have flattened at the beginning of the 21st century despite global warming trends?
Expectation.Answer: The changes of the freezing/thawing index tended to be flat at the beginning of the 21st century, possibly due to variations in climate patterns that temporarily counteract the general warming trend, affecting the spatial-temporal distribution of the index.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might arise in ensuring the accuracy and completeness of a dataset covering global land temperature observations from 1973 to 2021, and how could these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: One challenge is dealing with missing data for certain years at some stations. The decision not to interpolate missing data helps avoid uncertainty errors from interpolation and retains the data's authenticity and accuracy. However, this approach may leave gaps that could affect the comprehensiveness of the analysis. Ensuring consistent and continuous data collection methods globally could address this challenge.

Judgmental.Question: How might one evaluate the effectiveness of phylogeographic analysis and niche modeling in assessing the impacts of past climate cooling on species distribution, especially in diverse montane lake ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness can be evaluated by examining how well the phylogeographic analysis and niche modeling capture historical distribution patterns and predict future changes. This could involve comparing model predictions with known historical data and understanding how well these approaches incorporate diverse ecological factors specific to montane lake ecosystems. Further validation could be achieved by cross-referencing with independent data sources and adjusting models for regional specificity.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods ensure the accuracy and continuity of freezing/thawing indices across global land even when there are missing years at some stations.
Assertion.Answer: The datasets do not fill in missing years at stations to avoid the uncertainty and error that interpolation might introduce, thus prioritizing the authenticity and accuracy of the data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the spatial distribution characteristics of freezing/thawing indices are affected by both latitude and altitude.
Assertion.Answer: The freezing/thawing index exhibits obvious climatic distribution characteristics influenced by latitude and altitude, with the global warming trend being more pronounced in high latitudes and altitudes, particularly in the cold season.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the challenges associated with maintaining the accuracy and continuity of data collection for assessing freezing/thawing indices on a global scale.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include dealing with data gaps due to missing years at some stations, which were not filled to avoid interpolation errors and to maintain data authenticity and accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify strategies for improving the understanding of spatial and temporal variation characteristics of freezing/thawing indices globally, considering both latitude and altitude effects.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies could include analyzing the collected daily temperature data from over 14,000 global stations, focusing on the latitude and altitude impacts on freezing/thawing indices, and discussing their relationship with geographical factors.
